content_flow.text: The slide is titled "Data Mining". It asks "What is data mining?" and provides the answer: "Seeking unexpected pearls of wisdom". It also lists the "Origins of data mining" with a diagram showing Data Mining at the center, connected to Statistics, Pattern Recognition, Machine Learning, AI, Database, and Data Warehousing.

The slide is titled "Why Data Mining?". It lists two reasons: "Traditional techniques may be unsuitable due to Enormity of data" and "High dimensionality of data". It also shows images related to Traffic Patterns and Cyber Security, and a graphic representing E-Commerce and IOT.

Why Data Mining? Traditional techniques may be unsuitable due to Enormity of data. Huge data. For example, certain statistic methodology is good for not huge data. Maybe or not good for certain data. And then like cybersecurity. So, for example, if you went to high school barefoot right there, you'll find out there have a lot of traffic data. And then like cybersecurity. And but how do you know which action are related to hacker? So you need to do certain mining about that. So cybersecurity actually is also because the data is quite large. You need to do something somehow dig out of them. And sometimes it's also because our data have called something we call high dimensionality. Which means that X is one dimension, Y is one dimension. But in data mining, we usually have a lot of dimension, thousand or 10,000 or millions of dimension. Why? Because each feature we consider them as a dimension. Each feature as considered as a dimension. So, for example, if you went to e-commerce. This is my browsing history. Every browsing history, you will have a lot of feature. Which book you try to check? How many customer, how many books, how many video? Each one of them. Just imagine in those e-commerce store. The dimensionality is high enough, like millions or trillions of the thing right there. Also, the data mining also try to take care of certain thing we call heterogeneous data. What is called heterogeneous data? So I hope everyone heard of certain thing called IOT, Internet of Things. Internet of Things is like we have so many devices, all connected through internet. Each devices have their own record, okay? Each devices have their own record, have their own attribute, have different way. So then if you want to somehow try to integrate all the data through the different devices, the data resources also might have different type of them. So that is why we call them heterogeneous. Or maybe you heard about something called homogeneous, which means if they are the same, all of them are uniform. They are coming from the same type. Data mining, we try to emphasize on the data might be heterogeneous.

The slide is titled "Different Emphases of Courses". It lists "Data Mining" (Pattern discovery in large datasets) and "Data Science" (End-to-end data analysis: cleaning, analyzing, and visualizing; Machine learning for learning from data; Artificial Intelligence: Mimicking human intelligence in machines). It shows a Venn diagram illustrating the overlap between Data Mining and Data Science.
